Questions: How do you grab a reader's attention?
Answers:
Easy.

Single word sentences.

Followed by short sentences.

Then you can move in to longer, flowing sentences that contain the “meat” of what you want to tell your readers. This method works well for me. I guess that, by the time they’ve made it to the fourth paragraph (which doesn’t take long, because the first three paragraphs are short), people figure they’ve made it this far, they might as well finish it.

And just like that, you’ve gotten their attention.

The worst thing to do is to hit them from the beginning with a huge paragraph. People are lazy. You can count on that. If the first thing they encounter seems like work, they won’t do it.

But look at my first “paragraph”. You can’t look at it and NOT read it. Your brain processed that word quicker than you could decide you didn’t want to read it.

Questions: What is your favorite cooking site or blog?
Answers:
My favorite favorite favorite is Hebbars Kitchen.

The recipes are Indian, vegetarian, and delicious. And there are a ton of them.

She includes step by step photos and doesn’t have the super annoying long intros that a lot of food blogs have.

I love her so much.

Questions: Where do I find bloggers to share my videos?
Answers: First of all, if you do not have a partnership with a certain blogger it is really hard that they do unless they like them. And even if you do have a partnership, the actual advertising will not be successful if it is too obviously advertised. The catch of this, is to find a blogger that aligns with your business goals and the ideology behind your product.

Questions: What tips & suggestions would experienced bloggers give to young bloggers?
Answers:
I've been blogging for almost eight years now and have been doing it professionally for four years. I get asked this question all of the time.

First, I think it's important to be realistic about what blogging is. So let's start with a few misconceptions people have about blogs:

Most blogs don't make any money. And if they do, it took them multiple years to get there. As a business plan, blogs suck. They take years and thousands of hours of work to ramp up to a level where you can monetize them. And in many cases the methods you use to monetize them kill your brand and tarnish your writing's credibility, making them impossible to turn into money-makers.

I don't know the real numbers but I would estimate that 99% of blogs out there have no significant readership, and of those blogs that have a significant readership, 99% of those make little or no money.

So now that I've dumped ice water all over your world-conquering blogging aspirations, let me just say, there are only two valid reasons to start a blog. Either a) you have some other business and blogging would be a nice way to help promote it. Or b) you just really, really, really enjoy blogging. Outside of those two reasons, there's no legitimate reason to start one.

(Edit: a commenter pointed out that there is a legitimate third reason, and that is to build a platform to eventually get a book deal and/or to test ideas for a book. This is very true. But even so, you're looking at a couple years of writing to build a platform large enough to get a publisher's attention.)
A lot of bloggers, even successful bloggers, are shitty writers. No offense, but most bloggers can't write well. Most bloggers are successful not because of their writing but because they found a good niche market to insert themselves into. They're successful because they're solving a problem for people and are serving a practical purpose.

What I'm saying is, is that most bloggers are successful because they're good marketers, not because they're good writers. Take that however you want to.

Writing well is hard. It's a skill that takes years of conscious effort to develop. And if you've gone through the trouble to develop it, chances are you don't need to be blogging. You're working at a magazine or writing The Next Great American Novel or something.

With all of that said, I will tell you this. The better your writing is, the better your chances of blogging success are. Good writing never goes out of style. And truly great writing cannot be suppressed. A great article on a great topic written beautifully will be successful no matter where it is or who wrote it. Guaranteed.
Until you've written hundreds of thousands of words, you have no clue what you will enjoy writing about or what other people will enjoy reading from you. Successful blogs exist at the intersection between the passions of the writer and readers. The problem is that everyone, despite thinking they know where those two passions are, don't actually know either until they've put their reps in.

Until you've written 100 pages about a topic, you really don't know how much you enjoy writing about it. And until you've published 100 pages about a topic, you have no idea how much people will enjoy reading what you have to say about it.

It takes a lot of writing and experimentation for each person to find their own individual style and voice, what they care about, what others care about, and so on. This is a natural process. But it just so happens that when you blog, you need to go through this process in a very public way. Which is awkward. And kind of embarrassing.

But you need to be able to stomach this. Most people, when they want to start blogging don't realize how much embarrassment and "I can't believe I actually published that," goes into it. So if you can't handle public embarrassment (not to mention the occasional hate email), then, as the South Park ski instructor once said, "you're going to have a bad time!"

It's for the three reasons above that my go-to advice for aspiring bloggers is always, "Write 100 posts and then come back and ask me again."

Because until you've written 100 posts, you generally have no clue what you enjoy writing about or what people enjoy reading from you, you have not developed anything close to decent writing chops, and you have no chance at ever monetizing.

Because until you find that unique voice, and until you get your writing chops up to speed, there's not much that can be said other than, "Keep writing. Keep experimenting. Keep testing out new ideas and seeing who responds." Hell, start three blogs. Write a post a week for each one. Write a fan fiction. A tech manual. A sci-fi fantasy novel starring Steve Jobs and Elon Musk. The more creative, the better. Eventually you'll find something that sticks.

So that's my go-to answer. But in the meantime, here is some other advice to keep in mind as you join the rest of us in fighting the great tyranny that is the blinking cursor:

Study branding and basic marketing. Even if you're a fiction blogger. Even if you have no intention of ever making money off blogging. Even if you're writing erotica about dwarves and elves. Understanding branding and the basics of marketing (finding a niche, differentiating yourself, unique selling points, etc.) will go further in helping you establish an audience than anything else you can do aside from better writing.

Writing first, design second. Download a nice-looking free Wordpress theme and just run with it until you get a decent-sized audience. Then worry about making your site look beautiful later. Unless you're blogging to a entrepreneur/professional audience, design really doesn't matter much. As a blogger, you will live and die by the quality of your writing and the quality of your message. Design is just the cherry on top.
Read books, not other bloggers. I know I keep saying this, but most bloggers are not good writers. Most of them have built popular blogs off of a brilliant brand or because they are solving a clear problem. I.e., they're popular because of smart marketing, not smart writing. Definitely read successful bloggers to get ideas about branding and marketing. But when it comes to writing itself, you need to be reading writers. Find the best books in the genre or subject you want to be writing about and then pay attention to how they write. Practice mimicking their style and their tone. Read the classics of your genre. Read the greats like Hemingway, Dickens, Tolstoy. Try to figure out what makes them great. Then practice mimicking them. See how it feels. Steal a few stylistic things. Leave others behind.
You want quality traffic first, quantity second. That means no spamming, no black hat SEO nonsense, no viral-baiting a million 10-second visitors with a goofy cat video. Do your work. Put it out there. Then wait and see. Traffic is nice, but you're looking for engagement, for subscribers, for followers, for people who care.
At first, the only people who will care about your blog will be your friends and family. If even they don't care, well, then you're way off-track. Start over. When you finally get something good, not only will your friends and family care, but you'll start noticing friends of friends, old acquaintances, co-workers, etc. popping up. This is a good sign. The better your blog gets, the more the degrees of separation will expand outward.
Set a word goal each week and then attempt to keep it for a year. When I started, I promised myself at least 3 posts of 1000 words each week. I kept that up for almost three years. Sure, a lot of those posts were crap, but man, did it pay off. I improved a lot. I got much closer to finding my voice. And I discovered a lot about what people did/didn't want to read from me.
Proofread. Multiple times. Typos and bad grammar hurt your credibility and hurt the reader's experience. Take pride in your work. Be a perfectionist.
Have fun. At the end of the day, you need to enjoy writing/blogging, otherwise this is just going to be a vanity project that you'll scrap in a month. Blogging is a very lonely profession in many ways. It can also be stressful in weird ways. Like anything else, you really have to have a natural passion for the work if you're going to make it. You have to be in it for the right reasons. So try it out for a few months or a year, and if you still aren't excited to be posting, then perhaps chalk it up as a nice attempt and then go try something else.

Sure, a lot of those posts were crap, but man, did it pay off. I improved a lot. I got much closer to finding my voice. And I discovered a lot about what people did/didn't want to read from me.
Proofread. Multiple times. Typos and bad grammar hurt your credibility and hurt the reader's experience. Take pride in your work. Be a perfectionist.
Have fun. At the end of the day, you need to enjoy writing/blogging, otherwise this is just going to be a vanity project that you'll scrap in a month. Blogging is a very lonely profession in many ways. It can also be stressful in weird ways. Like anything else, you really have to have a natural passion for the work if you're going to make it. You have to be in it for the right reasons. So try it out for a few months or a year, and if you still aren't excited to be posting, then perhaps chalk it up as a nice attempt and then go try something else.', 'aiModelVersion': '1'}

Questions: Has Dr. Meghann Kaiser written a book or have a blog?
Answers:
I promise, I am not answering my own question.

But a few people have asked, so I am taking this opportunity to answer.

With the help of many, many Quorans (why does Quora spell check its own name?), I am assembling a short collection of the autobiographical essays and vignettes I have posted. The subject matter will focus on my experiences as a doctor, a patient, and a human being who also happens to be a doctor and a patient. Quora has acted like a beta testing ground, where I have received encouragement, suggestions, edits, and even the occasional tip on how to publish. All things that I am enormously grateful for. Any additional help, feedback, or just stray thoughts you can provide is always much appreciated.

The book is tentatively titled “Most of Me Left,” and I am ramping up efforts with a final burst of productivity, in the hopes that it will be ready for publication through Amazon in the early New Year 2020. I will keep you posted, since it is truly a book by all of us, and I am thankful every day. Sincerely.

Questions: What is the difference between Quora and Medium? Which one is better? Why?
Answers:
Ah, the great Quora V. Medium debate.

It’s not too great, but, ey’, 200+ people are following this question, so that’s great to me!

In all honesty, the two sites are better than… whatever in the world is happening at that Yahoo “Answers” we see.

First, let’s get into what the two sites are.

Medium is, as the company defines it as: a place to read, write, and interact with the stories that matter most to you. Every day, thousands of voices read, write, and share important stories on Medium.

In other words, a glorified way to say that it’s a place where you can write articles about stuff and have it be shared to the internet.

Quora is, as the company defines it as: a place to gain and share knowledge. It's a platform to ask questions and connect with people who contribute unique insights and quality answers. This empowers people to learn from each other and to better understand the world.

In other words, quite an interesting version of just saying that it’s a Q&A site. Oddly enough, unlike most of the internet, the “knowledge” part actually holds up with people here!

Most people on Medium will say Medium is better, and most people on Quora will say Quora is better.

Even those who are on both sites, like me, will be biased towards one of the sides.

For example, I say Quora’s better, but that’s probably because Quora has helped me through dark points in time and I’ve been using Quora almost daily for 14 months as of January, 2018.

So, instead, let’s look at the pros and cons of both sites:

Medium’s pros.
Medium can pay you. Need I say more?
Medium has intelligent writers discussing important issues.
Medium has a great fan base, and is even more popular than that of Quora.
Medium optimizes your feed in better ways than Quora with its’ AI systems.
Medium uses claps, a rather more sophisticated form of the primitive “upvote” in which allows you to give anywhere between 1 and 50 claps to a single article.
You can decide what picture you want for your article, unlike Quora.
Medium doesn’t rely on random questions to come for a user to answer them. Users can just write if they want to.
Medium has an amazing community in which any user can fall back to, share any of their stories with - all without fools.
Medium’s cons.
It’s incredibly hard to get popular there. Sure, only about 30 million Medium users go on there monthly as opposed to Quora’s 200 million, but that doesn’t make it easy. If anything, you need to outsource to other sites like Reddit to make you popular.
As of January 20th, 2018, I have a measly 2 followers on Medium. But I have 205 amazing people following me and reading my content on Quora.

Sheldon Paterson – Medium

Daniel Paterson

Medium has no clear cut way to just write about a certain topic. When you come to Medium, you’re expected to write. When you come to Quora, you write based on questions that people make. Because of this, unless if you can think of a great idea to write about, you ain’t going to be using Medium as a medium.
Pun intended.
Most of Medium’s articles are in the six to seven minute range. This isn’t so bad for people who like to sit down and read, but, if you’re reading an article quickly, you aren’t going to sit down to read something that’s worth your whole lunch break.

Now for Quora!

Quora’s pros.
Quora, just like Medium, also has an amazing community in which people will support you every step of the way.
Most of Quora’s answers are short and concise. They aren’t long articles, unlike Medium.
Quora mainly only has articles in the form of answers to questions. If you can’t think of what to write, that’s fine - just answer this query!
You can ask virtually any (appropriate) question on Quora and get logical responses from logical people. Hence as to why Quora got its’ name from the word Quorum!
Quora’s cons.
Quora’s BNBR system. In all honesty, Quora has a decent track record, but it can just be too harsh with its’ banning. I see at least one popular writer being banned every month (eg. Brooke Schwartz’s recent ban), sometimes with little to no explanation or for just ridiculous reasons.
You get a ban, you get a ban, you all get a ban!
The problem with this is that, this has led to even famous Quorans falling onto Medium. It could be possible that this banning outrage may cause refugee crisis into Medium.
Quora isn’t the place to make blogs, people. Even “popular” blogs on Quora get, like what, 50 upvotes per good post at most? Medium sure is, but Quora? Eh… no.
Quora has a defined structure in place. You ask questions, you get answers. You find a question, you answer it. If you really want to write about something, well, honey, you better find the write question about it!
Pun, once again, intended.
Quora is partially turning into Facebook. Questions such as “What is the most Indian thing ever?” is now becoming commonplace. Though I say it is also a pro that you can talk about funny things more often than on Medium (seriously, some of the answers to that query is just hilarious), it also has it’s downfalls.

So now you know the pros and cons to Medium and Quora.

And who is the winner?

DRUMROLL PLEASE!

“Drums.”

Neither one is the winner.

In fact, it all depends on what you want.

You like long articles about random but empowering topics? Medium is for you.

You like short answers with concise information? Quora is for you.

You like a place to make a blog? Medium is for you.

You like a place to write anecdotes and funny situations? Quora is for you.

It all just depends on your preference. I, personally, prefer Quora, but I love using both.

And, if you haven’t tried both of them, try giving the one you haven’t tried a twirl to see if you like it or not.

Who knows, it could be the next best thing since sliced liver meat.

Questions: How important was blogging to OkCupid's success?
Answers: Very important. We think. OkCupid's most popular blogs posts were read by millions of people, and that was excluding existing OkCupid users.  Still, we don't really have any way of measuring the effects, since direct signups from the blog posts were just a few thousand people each. But over the long run, we just kept hearing how everyone *loved* the posts so much, and that it was one of the big reasons they loved the site. All that said, I get this question a lot from startups who are hoping to fill in the "how do we grow?" blank by saying "Well, we'll just write a blog, like OkCupid did."  Maybe hire a "data scientist."  And unfortunately, I have to advise against it in almost all cases. Some bullets: OkCupid's blog worked because we had sexy data. If you're doing a real estate startup, or a housing thing, or an ad network, or even some social/photo/sharing tool, odds are you don't have the wealth of personal information to produce lots of great posts. Maybe 1 or 2 posts. In contrast, on a whim at OkCupid, if we wanted to know whether our users had ever done thing X with a Y on hand while thinking about Z, we could get a few hundred thousand answers in a couple days.  Further, we had pretty deep demo data. We had Christian Rudder writing the blog.  Yes, he studied math at Harvard, but the math on OkTrends was high school level. And with a lot of statistical hand-waving and over-simplification. His posts were great because he's such an amazing writer, not because he's awesome at math. (He's certainly the best writer I know.)The posts each took 4-8 weeks of full-time work for him to write. Plus another 2-4 weeks of dedicated programming time from someone else on the team.  It's easy to look at an OkTrends post, with all its simple graphs and casual writing style and think someone just threw it together, but it probably had 50 serious revisions. And we threw out a lot of research that didn't turn into good posts.  Your startup probably can't afford to do this. It shouldn't waste like 10 man weeks of effort/focus/money on writing a blog post.  Most other attempts I've seen at boosting traffic via blogging have failed. Obviously we can all point at exceptions (selection bias), but when I think of all the examples of someone telling me in advance they were doing a blog, they failed.Btw, last thing: I know I used past-tense to describe the blog, but Christian still is at OkCupid and he's doing a lot of data research again...

Questions: What is James Altucher's secret for blogging so consistently?
Answers:
About 24 years ago I started writing every day because I thought if I got a novel published I would get girls to like me. I also felt like I couldn't get a job in the real world unless I had a published novel.

I don't know why I thought these things. I was an idiot and still largely am. But you are what you eat so I ended up without any girlfriends and with no job.

But I wrote every day.

And before I wrote every day I read every day. I never read in high school or college. But suddenly I was reading every book i could find. And then after I read a book I would go to the library and look up all the criticism of that book.

Then I'd comb through all the literary journals and read every story I could find.

Then I'd go home and write. I wrote about 4 novels. I wrote about 50 or more short stories. I also got 1000s of rejection letters.

All my friends got sick of me because I would force them to read all of my stuff and give me critiques.

And, of course, I couldn't handle any criticism.

So I started to have no girlfriend, no job, and no friends. But I still read and wrote every day.

And still do.

2-4 hours of reading to start off the morning (I wake up very early) and then 2-4 hours of writing before I even consider answering emails or doing my normal business stuff. And then I usually end the day with reading.

Seven days a week. I feel physically ill on days I don't do this.

The only time I took a break from this routine in the past 24 years was when I worked at HBO. I was doing a project for their website that I called "3am". I went out and interviewed prostitutes and drug dealers at three in the morning every Tuesday night for almost three years.

This, of course, gave me more material to write about.

Then I started a bunch of businesses and made and lost a lot of money.

This gave me more material to write about.

Then, as you get older you make enemies, lose friends, encounter interesting people, risk your life, do stupid things, get divorced, get people pregnant, and lots of things happen.

And each one of those things can be "thin-sliced". You start a company (big slice), which means you might have sex with an employee and then get them pregnant. (thinner slice)

This, as a hypothetical example, gives you something to write about. Abortion. And other fun topics.

Every day I write one or more posts. Most posts I don't post. Yesterday I wrote a post: 5 things I learned from my taxi driver. On the side he is the chauffeur for four high end call girls. I asked him a lot of questions. He was free with his answers and named names. I wrote the post but will probably never publish it.

Some days I can't think of what to write. But I stare at the screen and write whatever I want. Nobody can stop me.

Then when I think I have something good, I paste it into a Facebook status update window. For whatever reason, this forces me to edit very tightly.

After about 10-15 passes, my final post is about 30% smaller than my original post.

Then the post is ready.

Then I hope you like it.

But before that happens, I'm writing another post.

Questions: Does minifying HTML and CSS codes increase web page speed?
Answers:
Yes, but…

Let’s take Bootstrap as an example. Bootstrap might reasonably be called a…err, rather heavyweight framework. It’s chonky.

Artist’s impression of Bootstrap

The ‘normal’ Bootstrap 4 CSS file is 187KB. The minified version is 147KB, for a savings of 21%.

Sounds nice, right? That should mean 21% faster load times, right?

Well, no, because (a) most of the page isn’t in the Bootstrap framework, it’s in the HTML and images and such, and (b) more importantly, the Bootstrap CSS file only downloads once, and is called up from the cache as you browse the site.

So it’ll increase the download speed of the Bootstrap CSS file, not the entire page, by 21%, the first time you look at a page on that site, and from then on, the time savings is exactly zero because the file is cached by your browser.

So yes, but really no, because the savings is quite marginal—in this case, 20kb of download saved one time on the first page view.

There are more effective ways to increase speed. The two biggest are to make sure you’re using a fast database server with an efficient database if you’re using a DB site, and optimize images, which typically are going to be much larger than the HTML/CSS size of the site. (For example, don’t use 3000-pixel-wide images that you display 400 pixels wide in your HTML, okay?)

You’ll also likely get a lot further by removing unused elements from your CSS and Javascript than by minifying them, if you really want to shave off file size.

Questions: What are the best, insightful blogs about data, including how businesses are using data?
Answers:
Popular Culture


Nate Silver: http://www.fivethirtyeight.com
Carl Bialik: http://blogs.wsj.com/numbersguy/
Freakonomics: http://freakonomics.blogs.nytimes.com/


Databases and Data Infrastructure


Curt Monash blogs at http://www.dbms2.com and primarily discusses software for data management.
Tony Bain writes in a similar vein at http://www.tonybain.com.
Dan Abadi is a top young database researcher and blogs at http://dbmsmusings.blogspot.com.
Joe Hellerstein, one of the most accomplished database researchers out there, blogs at http://databeta.wordpress.com.
Mike Stonebraker, David DeWitt, Sam Madden, and some of the other professors behind the Vertica technology blog at http://databasecolumn.vertica.com.
Donald Feinberg is one of the most respected analysts in the field; he blogs for Gartner at http://blogs.gartner.com/donald-feinberg.
James Kobelius holds a similar position at Forrester; he blogs at http://blogs.forrester.com/information_management/business_intelligence/.
Merv Adrian is an independent analyst with a deep knowledge of the space. He blogs at http://mervadrian.wordpress.com.


Machine Learning and Data Mining


John Langford, who works at Yahoo! Research NYC, blogs at http://hunch.net.
Olivier Bousquet, one of my favorite machine learning researchers, has a (dead) blog at http://ml.typepad.com.
Mike Driscoll blogs at http://dataspora.com/blog.
Gordon Linoff and Michael Berry blog at http://www.data-miners.com/blog.


Data Visualization


Visual Complexity: http://www.visualcomplexity.com/vc/blog
Jeff Heer: http://jheer.org/blog


Text Mining and Natural Language Processing

I'll come back to this one. Too many to list right now!

Random Updates


http://www.bigdatalove.com: Chris Smith in Utah

Questions: What advice would you give to new writers/upcoming Quorans?
Answers:
As a Quoran who has been here for 5+ years, I have pretty much seen it all.

So here is my inputs for new / upcoming Quorans.

Be Nice Be Respectful (BNBR). This is the foundation of all Quora policies. Follow this to the hilt. Forget being disrespectful to others. Don’t even call your own self a fool. My answer was collapsed just because I called myself an asshole.
Have no expectations. Just because you have followed a popular Quoran, do not expect them to follow you back or upvote your answers. Or expect them to promptly respond back to your answer comments or inbox messages. Remember that they would be getting lots of messages and they also have a life outside of Quora.
Addiction. Remember this. At some point, Quora can become an addiction. Just don’t forget the other aspects of your life, apart from Quora.
Grammar: A lot many people will tell you to write in proper Grammar. I will tell you otherwise. Just write. And write as if you were talking one on one with someone. That will make your answer more relatable to people here. I do this all the time. And if someone suggests “Edits” to your answer, be thankful for it. He / She read your answer and took out the time to work on it.
Stay away from hate. If you have written any controversial answer, and if answer comments start getting hateful or getting on your nerves, don’t respond back, just simply disable comments on the answer. It’s blissful and will put you at peace. And don’t get worked up if your answer gets downvoted or collapsed. Just move on. That’s life.
Inbox Messaging. It’s really upto you if you want your inbox open for messaging from all, only your followers or not open to anyone. And if you get hateful or stupid messages, don’t engage in a war of wits. It’s just not worth your time and effort. Just Report and Block the person. It’s as simple as that.
Top Writers / Popular Quorans. You will eventually see Quorans who have the Top Writer Tag on their profile or Quorans who have tens of thousands of followers and are immensely popular. Don’t aspire to be them. They are not aliens from another planet. They are just humans like you and me. Never get into a race to be a Popular Quoran. It’s just temporary. In the real world, no one will recognize you inspite of you having 50 thousand followers on Quora.
Followers. If you want followers, follow others too. If you want upvotes on your answers, upvote other answers too. If you want to get to know fellow Quorans, follow them, interact with them on their answers and commenting on it. Never inbox a Quoran unless they have specifically mentioned that they are open to messaging. Interacting with them on their answers are a great way to become familiar with them and eventually becoming friends with them.
Honesty. Lastly, this is what I want to say. Just be your self. Be honest and truthful in your answers and who you really are. Just don’t fake it to be popular.

Questions: Why was the blog “Duly Blocked” deleted?
Answers:
Duly Blocked was something I started. On Quora, you’re not supposed to directly interact with the people who harass you. If you have a complaint against an individual, your only recourse is to report and block. This, especially if you’re the target of constant abuse, can be pretty demoralizing. The blog was an attempt to give people an opportunity to release some steam without actually showing the name of their harasser. You could document what you’d been on the receiving end of and get some validation and support from a friendly audience.

Troll Control Patrol was a bit more active. That was an attempt to develop a rapid response team to quickly identify and report trolls. The idea was that Moderation was clearly not acting quickly enough, and that with the help of some community policing, trollish behavior could come to their attention much faster.

They were both deleted because I was asked to delete them.

Many people believe that patrolling the trolls is tantamount to feeding them, and that the very publicity they generate encourages their behavior. Quora Moderation subscribes to this theory. I disagree. For me, community policing is the most effective form of policing. But this is not my site. And so, when I was asked to delete the blogs, I duly complied.

That’s about it. Some people are talking about taking the fight off site. I wish them well.

My watch is ended.

On Quora, you’re not supposed to directly interact with the people who harass you. If you have a complaint against an individual, your only recourse is to report and block. This, especially if you’re the target of constant abuse, can be pretty demoralizing. The blog was an attempt to give people an opportunity to release some steam without actually showing the name of their harasser. You could document what you’d been on the receiving end of and get some validation and support from a friendly audience.

Troll Control Patrol was a bit more active. That was an attempt to develop a rapid response team to quickly identify and report trolls. The idea was that Moderation was clearly not acting quickly enough, and that with the help of some community policing, trollish behavior could come to their attention much faster.

They were both deleted because I was asked to delete them.

Many people believe that patrolling the trolls is tantamount to feeding them, and that the very publicity they generate encourages their behavior. Quora Moderation subscribes to this theory. I disagree. For me, community policing is the most effective form of policing. But this is not my site. And so, when I was asked to delete the blogs, I duly complied.

That’s about it. Some people are talking about taking the fight off site. I wish them well.

Questions: What are effective strategies for driving traffic to a new blog using social media platforms such as Facebook, Twitter, and Reddit?
Answers:
Here are some effective strategies for driving traffic to a new blog using social media platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and Reddit:

Content is King:

High-quality content: Focus on creating valuable, engaging, and informative content that resonates with your target audience. This will establish your blog as a reliable source of information and encourage people to share it.
Variety is key: Experiment with different content formats like articles, infographics, videos, and podcasts to cater to diverse preferences and keep your audience interested.
Headlines matter: Craft catchy and informative headlines that accurately reflect your content and entice users to click.

Tailoring your approach:

Know your audience: Understand who your ideal reader is and choose platforms where they are most active.
Optimize your profiles: Include a clear bio, captivating visuals, and links to your blog across all your social media profiles.
Post consistently: Maintain a regular posting schedule to keep your audience engaged and coming back for more.

Engagement and interaction:

Share, share, share!: Share your blog posts on relevant social media groups, communities, and forums. Cross-promote your content across platforms to amplify reach.
Engage with your audience: Respond to comments and messages promptly, answer questions, and participate in discussions related to your niche. This builds rapport and encourages further engagement.
Collaborations: Partner with other bloggers or social media influencers in your niche to reach a wider audience and explore cross-promotion opportunities.

Platform-specific tactics:

Facebook: Leverage Facebook groups to share your content and engage in targeted discussions. Utilize paid advertising options to reach a wider audience based on demographics and interests.
Twitter: Use relevant hashtags to increase discoverability, participate in trending topics, and engage in conversations with industry experts. Consider running Twitter polls or Q&A sessions to boost interaction.
Reddit: Find relevant subreddits where your target audience congregates and contribute valuable content in the form of posts or comments. Avoid blatant self-promotion, but subtly share your blog's expertise whenever appropriate.

Additional tips:

Utilize social media analytics: Track your performance on each platform to understand what resonates with your audience and optimize your strategy accordingly.
Social media scheduling tools: Consider using scheduling tools to streamline your posting and ensure consistent presence across platforms.
Run contests and giveaways: Host contests or giveaways related to your content to incentivize engagement and attract new followers.

Remember, building a successful online presence takes time and effort. Be patient, consistent, and adaptable in your approach to see your blog traffic grow steadily over time.

I hope these strategies help you drive traffic to your new blog!

Questions: When is the best time to start a blog?
Answers:
Best time: 10 years ago.

Second best time: Now.

You should absolutely not wait until you become an "expert" at something to start blogging about it. In fact, blogging about some topic is, in my opinion, the fastest and most robust (and enjoyable) way to go from being a beginner to an expert in any topic.

Writing a blog will force you to reasearch and learn about the topic. It will also put you in touch with other like-minded people. And, if you do reasonably well, it will put you in touch with the real experts from whom you'll be able to learn, by osmosis, if nothing else.

And before you realize it, you will be viewed as an expert in that topic.

Questions: Why do vulgar posts visit more than scientific and literary posts?
Answers:
Because here’s the thing. Whenever I did scientific or technical copy, it would get a few readers who wanted to know what something did or how to make something do it. Usually it would go into filing cabinet somewhere and be dragged out three or four times a year if it was lucky. It was utilitarian, and being utilitarian, it was straightforward and bone-dry.

When I did humorous copy, it would go in a mag. Several thousand people would read it and laugh. Some would e-mail back.

Anybody who spends their life reading only serious work is in danger of becoming dull. Really, really dull. And people do not listen to the dull because it’s like listening to an automaton. Even if they don’t know the phrase “bon-mot” people do like a good bon-mot.

Vulgarity, when well done, is an art form in itself. Shakespeare was full of ‘em. Like Cleopatra’s hand maiden suggesting that Mardian the Eunuch might be better at billiards. Do you remember Dharma and Greg? There was an extended joke about whether Kitty’s cushion had made the embarrassing noise or whether it was a “blame the dog” incident. It was bloody hilarious. One episode of Fawlty Towers has Basil accidentally groping a young woman’s breast whilst looking for a light switch. Remember Allo Allo? Burlesque as all get out. Top BBC show for years on end.

People like to think when they’ve got to and laugh when they haven’t. Those that have little in the way of a sense of humour usually find they might be good at what they do but are social failures. We are not sheep. You don’t see sheep cracking off a willy gag at each other. Talking fauna likes to stop talking every once in a while and laugh. Everybody does it. Even the French. Even the Germans. Yes, the Germans. And they have mugs like this:

Socially, one has to appreciate a well-presented vulgarity. Otherwise one may be mistaken for an accountant. Or worse, a sociology student. Or worse still, a Californian, and if one is mistaken for such one might as well give up all hope of ever leading a normal life.

And thus, on Quora, a question I answered four hours ago and deliberately misinterpreted to make my answer about drag queens has had more views than a serious answer I did four days ago about the nature of comedy. People like to be entertained. You learn lots more when you laugh about it than you do when it’s a dry discourse.

I blame the EU. Urchuckles at der Punchline.

Questions: What are effective strategies for driving traffic to a new blog using social media platforms such as Facebook, Twitter, and Reddit?
Answers:
Social media can be a powerful tool to propel your blog from obscurity to online stardom, but navigating the ever-changing landscape of each platform can be tricky. Let's explore some effective strategies for driving traffic to your new blog using Facebook, Twitter, and Reddit:

Facebook:

Join relevant groups and communities: Facebook groups are goldmines for targeted engagement. Find groups centered around your blog's niche and participate actively, sharing valuable insights and links to your blog posts. Don't just drop links and run – provide genuine contributions to establish yourself as a knowledgeable member.
Run targeted ads: Facebook's ad platform allows you to laser-focus your reach on demographics, interests, and even online behavior. Craft compelling ad copy and visuals that pique curiosity and entice users to visit your blog.
Host Facebook Live sessions: Offer live Q&A sessions, behind-the-scenes glimpses, or even educational tutorials relevant to your blog's theme. Live video is a great way to connect with your audience in real-time and build stronger relationships.

Twitter:

Hashtags are your friends: Research and strategically use relevant hashtags in your tweets to increase discoverability. Don't go overboard with #spam, but choose targeted hashtags that your ideal audience is likely to follow.
Engage in conversations: Twitter thrives on interaction. Reply to comments, participate in relevant threads, and retweet valuable content. This helps build your network and expose your blog to a wider audience.
Run Twitter polls and contests: Interactive content generates buzz and encourages engagement. Ask your followers questions related to your blog's topic or run simple contests with your blog posts as prizes.

Reddit:

Find your niche subreddits: Reddit is a treasure trove of communities on every imaginable topic. Find subreddits relevant to your blog and become an active member. Share valuable content, answer questions, and participate in discussions without being overtly promotional.
Submit your blog posts to relevant subreddits: Each subreddit has its own rules, so be sure to read them carefully before submitting your content. Choose subreddits where your posts would add value and avoid self-promotion without context.
Host Reddit AMAs (Ask Me Anything): Redditors love AMAs. Offer to answer questions about your blog's topic or your expertise in general. This can be a great way to generate interest and drive traffic to your blog.

Remember, Rome wasn't built in a day. Building a loyal following on social media takes time and consistent effort. Be patient, provide value, and engage authentically with your audience. Over time, you'll see your blog traffic steadily climb, fueled by the power of social media.

Questions: How do you grab a reader's attention?
Answers:
#CringeyHashtag

How Do You Grab a Reader’s Attention?

6 WAYS! (YOU WON’T BELIEVE #3!!)

Restate the question
Include some random irrelevant clickbait photo
Give the reader some reason to keep reading even though #3 really isn’t any more interesting than the other points
Make a list with shortish points
Bold random words
If you’re still reading this answer then I guess I succeeded

Thanks, Buzzfeed, for inspiring this answer.

Questions: What are the top 10 software testing blogs and websites?
Answers:
Finding out bugs can be a lot of fun, and not only for testers, but it’s also for everyone who wants their application to be free of bugs. However, apart from online tutorials, manuals, and books, to increase your knowledge, find a quick help to some problem or stay tuned to all the latest news in the testing domain, you have to rely on software testing blogs.
Source: top 17 Software Testing Blogs
 that are deemed necessary for every software tester:

Guru99
DZone
Software Testing Tricks
Trishkhoo
LambdaTest
Software Testing Magazine
Satisfice
Automation Awesomeness
Thinking Tester
Software Testing Material

Questions: How much money can I earn per each Medium article read on average?
Answers:
It actually pays really well — potentially. This article got picked up by Google, and got a big spike in external views (that top blue spike) then was distributed to Medium members.

16,200 internal views, and 715 dollars is 4–5 cents per internal view — and that’s about what I average, around 3–7 cents. External views don’t count for much — it’s the paying medium members that actually determine how much you get paid. You can see here this story started getting picked up by Google, which increases external views, but that doesn’t impact my bottom line.

The thing is, 4–5 cents per view is really good for the internet — if Quora was that generous, I’d be a multi-millionaire.

That’s 40–50 dollars per 1000 views — on YouTube, I’d earn 2–3 dollars per thousand views, and I’d have to put cringeworthy ads on my channel. On Medium, not so. And don’t even get me started about Quora, which has no monetization policy whatsoever for creators.

However, if you post without much of a following, and are not curated/distributed, you are far more likely to see something like this:

A bit of a barren landscape.

If you are starting out on Medium with no fanbase, you will see under a dollar per article in most cases. On Medium
, your fans directly contribute to how much you get paid — they get a membership, and their fees are distributed based on who they read.

So you might earn a thousand dollars per article or one cent, determined entirely by who is reading.

Questions: What are effective ways to turn a blog into a business?
Answers:
Harnessing Your Distinctive Perspective: The Key to Flourish in the Internet Business Sphere

I have had the honor to guide ambitious entrepreneurs like you initiate their path online by addressing questions and offering direction.

Today, I’m going to convey my knowledge on how to earn money online as a novice, without talents or background or starting capital, focusing on one paramount perspective:

“No individual on this planet has the exact life, experience, knowledge, or personality as you do. That means that you are unique and thus you have a distinctive outlook that you can offer to the world.”

The Power of Your Singular Outlook

Your distinctive viewpoint is your greatest possession in the world of digital entrepreneurship.

It empowers you to see chances and generate value in ways that others may not.

As a beginner, you may feel overwhelmed by the immense world of digital business, but remember that your singular background, experiences, and viewpoint can assist you stand out from the crowd and strike a chord with your target audience.

Finding Your Segment: A Foundation for Success

As a novice, it’s vital to find a niche that corresponds with your unique viewpoint and passions. This will make it more straightforward for you to create content, goods, or services that truly connect with your audience.

When picking a specialty, consider your interests, what you cherish doing or talking about, or learning. By selecting a specialty that you’re excited about, you’ll be more likely to continue and thrive in the long game.

Building Value through Genuineness

Authenticity is crucial to constructing a flourishing online enterprise.

By expressing your unique perspective and being genuine to yourself, you’ll be able to produce content that genuinely connects with your audience.

People can perceive when someone is real and excited about their work, and they’re more likely to believe and engage with authentic content.

Fostering a Growth Mindset

As you embark on your online entrepreneurial adventure, it’s crucial to develop a progressive mindset.

This means that you embrace challenges, view setbacks as learning opportunities, and believe that you can enhance your skills and knowledge over time.

By taking on a progressive mindset, you’ll be better prepared to face the unavoidable challenges that come with starting an online business and make consistent progress towards your goals.

Utilizing Your Singular Perspective to Monetize Your Online Enterprise

Once you’ve discovered your specialty, created genuine content, and developed a progressive mindset, it’s time to earn from your online venture.

There are various ways to generate money online, such as affiliate marketing, selling digital products, publicizing, and sponsored content.

As a newbie without starting capital, you may want to zero in on methods that require little upfront investment, such as affiliate marketing or creating digital products like e-books or online courses.

When picking a monetization strategy, consider how your distinctive viewpoint can add value to your audience.

As an example, if you’ve chosen a niche in sustainable living, you can create an e-book that shares your personal path towards a more eco-friendly lifestyle, with tips, tricks, and product recommendations.

By leveraging your unique outlook, you can create goods or services that truly help your audience and generate income for your online enterprise.

Staying Committed to Your Online Enterprise Journey

As a novice, it’s crucial to understand that creating a prosperous online enterprise takes time, endeavor, and devotion.

You may face setbacks or encounter hurdles along the way, but by staying faithful to your distinctive outlook and maintaining a development mindset, you can overcome these challenges and continue to advance.

One of the most vital aspects of entrepreneurship is learning from your mistakes and improving on your strategies.

As you navigate the world of online business, take the time to reflect on your progress, spot areas for improvement, and adapt your approach as required.

This continuous learning process will help you expand as an entrepreneur and ultimately reach victory in your chosen niche.

In conclusion, making money online as a beginner without skills, experience, or starting capital is achievable by utilizing your distinctive view.

By discovering a segment that matches with your passions, creating genuine content, developing a progressive mindset, and selecting monetization tactics that suit your audience, you can construct a flourishing online business that provides value to others and brings in income for yourself.

Remember to stay devoted to your journey, learn from your experiences, and regularly adapt your strategies as you grow and evolve as an entrepreneur.

If you found this advice valuable, my profile could be your next destination. It’s a collection of resources and advice for aspiring entrepreneurs. Have a look here: Quora

Questions: What steps do you take to ensure your writing is SEO optimized?
Answers:
Oh God. I don’t. SEO optimization is a scourge upon mankind, the new Fourth Horseman now that medical science has conquered pestilence despite the best efforts of the pro-plague set.

I loathe and despise SEO-optimized writing with every fiber of my being. A pox upon it and all those who embrace it. If you could comprehend the magnitude of my fiery hatred of SEO optimization, your hair would combust.

You know what I despise most about it? The way it wastes people’s time. It’s a form of psychic litter—small acts of immorality each too tiny to notice, but that have enormous cumulative impact.

Like, I abhor when I’m trying to solve a problem, so I do a Google search for something like, I don’t know, “3D printer print delaminating.” And you know what I see?

The first three pages of hits are all like this:

Are your 3D prints delaminating? In this article, we will show you what print delamination is, and how you can fix it. 3D printers sometimes suffer from prints that come apart between layers, or “delaminate.” Want to find out how to fix this problem? Read on! 3D printers are more popular than ever. Today, 3D printers make cheap, easy-to-afford products so everyone can get involved in the 3D printing craze. 3D printing is revolutionizing manufacture, with high-end 3D printers using techniques like laser sintering to create metal parts. Home 3D printers print plastic or resin. Blah blah blah blah blah blah blah…”

And then, 3,600 words later, in the second to the last paragraph: “Are your prints delaminating? Try increasing your print temperature gradually in 5-degree increments until the layers stick together.”

Search engines have inadvertently encouraged the wrong thing: web sites that appeal to bots, not that are useful to humans.

Questions: How do you grab a reader's attention?
Answers:
By making some crazy claim that seems too good to be true.

Put your crazy claim and main steps in bold. This helps them stand out.
Insert a random stock image. People love images, and will definitely draw their attention. Images also summarize what you’re talking about, and is a great way to let the reader know what you’re talking about.
Give a random statistic. As of August 12, 2017, 100% of respondents agreed that Zach Norman is a horrible writer.[1]
Add a random footnote for your statistic. Gotta cite your sources.
Give a quote from some person who seems to know what they’re doing when they probably don’t. According to Zach Norman, “Everyone should eat more Chipotle. It’s amazing and is the best fast food you can get.”
Insert a random pie chart and some random explanation in italics.

As you can see from this image, very many people strive to either go to the gym, get rich, or get promoted as their New Year’s resolution, as can be assumed from this totally real chart.

In conclusion, use these simple steps to grab a reader’s attention and get those views, followers, and upvotes in no time! Also be sure to ask for followers and thank people for upvotes in italics or bold to really piss them off.

Be sure to check out my blog that doesn’t exist, and please be sure to follow for more answers like this!

Footnotes

[1] http://quora.com/profile/lane-norman

Questions: What are effective strategies for driving traffic to a new blog using social media platforms such as Facebook, Twitter, and Reddit?
Answers:
Some effective strategies for driving traffic using social media platforms:

1. Use healthful content

This tip is not related to social media marketing but it is the essential first step that sets up all the other steps listed here today for success! So the content you produce must be useful, containing unique information.

2. Intriguing title:

A little change in the tone and style of your posts' titles may get you more exposure. This is because often email or RSS feed subscribers of your blog may have subscribed to other blogs in your niche too. With overcrowded information lists in their feed reader or inboxes, a creative title may save you from getting lost in the crowd.

3. Integrate social media with your blog.

By integrating social media into your blog, we mean bridging the gap between popular social media sites and your content. People who visit your blog need an easy way to connect with your blog and share your blog content via social media elements that are integrated into your site.

4.Share your blog Across your social media platforms:

If readers are not coming to your site, go to them instead. Share your blog posts on as many social media sites as you can. You are probably already doing this, as it's not rocket science. But getting certain things right will help your efforts:

5. Whole post updates:

Unlike other social media platforms that allow only a few text characters in updates, some social media platforms like Google+ and Tumblr actually allow you to display the whole blog post. At the end of the post you can give a link to the original blog post URL and this will get you some quality social media traffic.

6.Create relationship with other blogger is common sense to be aware of other bloggers in your niche, but what can you do with that information to help promote your own blog? Here are a few quick tips to use other blogger's influences on your own blog's social media.

Read and share other bloggers' posts and drop comments on them via Twitter to either appreciate or acknowledge the information shared. Make sure to @mention the blogger's Twitter handle. You can also post comments on the post page, but this method will immediately let the blogger know who is commenting.

7.Social Bookmark your blog post.

Social bookmark your blog posts on high profile sites such as Digg, Stumble Upon, Delicious and Reddit, which have a good audience-base. But remember, this strategy has been overused in the past, so much so that social bookmarking is not as effective as it once used to b

Questions: What are some differences between writing on Quora and writing on Medium?
Answers:
Writing on Quora has two main advantages:

The writing prompts are given to you, and
It’s much easier to find an audience.

If you’re new to Quora and are getting bummed by a lack of views, the trick is to answer questions that have a lot of followers.

For example, this question has 40k+ followers:

What can I learn/know right now in 10 minutes that will be useful for the rest of my life?

Just by answering that, you’re guaranteed at least a small audience. (A lot of that 40k is bots or long-forgotten accounts, but still, some of them are real people with active accounts.)

Once you build a follower count of your own, even your answers to barely followed questions will get an audience. This answer of mine that you’re reading right now… as of the time I’m writing this, only two people are following this question. Yet, because I have followers of my own, this will likely get dozens of views and several upvotes within about five minutes of me hitting “submit.”

I was doing pretty well for myself on Medium at the beginning of the year … growing my audience at a steady pace and improving my writing and making a few bucks from it all. But I quit going to that site near the end of May. The “woke/let’s make everything about race” crowd was taking it over, and my homepage, despite my attempts to curate it to my liking, was still becoming more toxic every day.

Actually I just checked it, for literally the first time in two months. This is what I was met with:

Keep in mind that this is after several months of me being active on Medium every day, and doing my best to like certain things, and mute certain other topics and authors, to personalize my Medium experience. Despite that, I have:

112 notifications. I should probably look into those.
Three out of five stories on my landing page that are about race.
One that seems to be anti-cop, or at least is going with the “cops are racist” angle.
A story about a woman feeling empowered by seeing another woman doing yoga in the nude.

This is actually an improvement for Medium compared to the daily progressive dribble that drove me away from the site two months ago.

I’m not saying that there’s anything wrong with any of these stories; if that’s what people want to write about, and what other people want to read about, more power to them. I’m just saying that I’m not the target audience for those stories, and I’ve tried my best to help Medium’s algorithm figure that out, but it’s all been for naught. It insists on pushing these stories on me.

Perhaps there just aren’t enough stories on that site of the type I’d actually like to read.

Medium has two big advantages over Quora, as far as I can tell:

You can make money creating content there, and
Your content is more likely to get picked up by a publication there.

I have made a few hundred dollars from my Medium content this year. The content I wrote back in the beginning of the year still makes money for me every month. Just not enough to convince me to begin writing on that site again, for a while at least.

Questions: How do I fix a blurry photo when I post from a blog and link to Facebook?
Answers:
Unfortunately, fixing a blurry photo after posting it depends on where the blur originated:

Before posting:

Use a high-quality image: Ensure the original photo isn't blurry. Resize and optimize for web if needed.
Check blog settings: Make sure your blog platform isn't compressing images excessively.

After posting:

Facebook preview issue: Re-share the link, manually choose a clear image, or clear Facebook cache.
Photo itself is blurry: Options are limited. Consider re-posting with a better image or using photo editing tools (with caution).

Remember: Fixing severe blurriness might not be possible. Focus on prevention for future posts.

Questions: How can I use backlinks to grow my blog?
Answers:
How To Build Backlinks

Backlinking should be one of the main priorities for your website SEO because of the importance of search engine ranking.

Posting
Write articles containing popular keywords that relate to your website/company/product. If you do not know where to start your keyword research for your site, this keyword tool
 can help you find what you are looking for.
Commenting
Posting comments on other articles that relate to your website or product can be beneficial. When you start commenting make sure to reference your website/product that relates to that article. You never know who is going to write an article about your site or give you a backlink.
Tracking
It’s important to keep track of your backlinks so that you know which websites are linking back to you. You can make an excel spreadsheet and keep track of the date, websites, contact information and comments.

Backlink Tools

Here are a few backlink tools to help you get started and monitor your links as well as your competitors.

Check My Links
 (Google Chrome Plugin)
Linkbird 
(Free/$)
Pitchbox
 ($)
Monitorbacklinks 
(Free/$)
Linkody 
(Free/$)

Get Started Now!

Building backlinks can be time-consuming but worthwhile. This should be one of your main priorities for your site’s SEO because of the importance of search engine ranking. I hope this article helped you to better understand backlinks, their effect on search engine rankings and why you should focus on building backlinks. Start backlinking today! If you need a tool to help you get ideas or related posts, check out this trending keyword too
l
.

Tell us your experience with backlink building! If you have any suggestions, questions or recommendations, feel free to leave a comment down below.

Questions: Which are the best SEO tools for a beginner?
Answers:
Conquering the Search Engine Jungle: Best SEO Tools for Beginners (No Experience Required!)

Feeling lost in the SEO wilderness? Don't worry, even seasoned explorers started somewhere! Navigating the world of search engine optimization (SEO) can seem daunting at first, but with the right tools, you can transform your website into a ranking machine. This guide will equip you, the SEO adventurer, with the perfect tools for your journey, tailored specifically for beginners.

Why Tools Matter:

Think of SEO tools as your trusty compass and map in this vast digital landscape. They help you:

Identify the right keywords: These are the search terms people use to find your content. Tools reveal hidden gems and competition levels for each keyword.
Optimize your website: Tools analyze your website, highlighting areas for improvement, from technical glitches to content clarity.
Track your progress: Just like measuring distance on a hike, tools show you how your website's ranking changes over time.
Stay ahead of the curve: SEO evolves, and tools keep you informed about the latest trends and best practices.

Free Essentials for Every Explorer:

Before diving into paid options, remember powerful tools exist at your fingertips for free:

Google Search Console: This official Google tool provides insights into how your website appears in search results, crawling errors, and valuable webmaster resources.
Google Analytics: Unveils your website's traffic sources, user behavior, and engagement, helping you understand your audience and tailor content accordingly.
Google Keyword Planner: This tool, within your Google Ads account, helps you discover relevant keywords and their search volume, offering a glimpse into the competitive landscape.
Yoast SEO Plugin (for WordPress): This plugin provides real-time feedback on your content, ensuring it's optimized for search engines and readers alike.

Paid Power-Ups for Advanced Exploration:

As you progress, consider these paid tools for deeper insights and advanced features:

SEMrush: An all-in-one powerhouse, offering comprehensive keyword research, competitor analysis, backlink tracking, and on-page optimization audits.
Ahrefs: Another popular choice, Ahrefs excels in backlink analysis, competitor research, and keyword research, providing detailed insights into your SEO strategy.
Moz Pro: This tool suite offers robust site audits, keyword research, and link analysis, helping you identify and fix technical SEO issues and build a strong backlink profile.
Ubersuggest: A free-to-paid tool from Neil Patel, offering keyword suggestions, site audits, and backlink analysis with a user-friendly interface.
Screaming Frog SEO Spider: This software crawls your website, identifying technical SEO issues like broken links and missing meta descriptions, perfect for technical audits.

Remember:

Start simple and focus on the basics. Don't overwhelm yourself with too many tools at once. Master the free essentials first.
Experiment and find what works for you. Different tools cater to different needs and learning styles. Try demos and free trials to discover the best fit.
SEO is a marathon, not a sprint. Be patient, consistent, and adapt your strategy based on data and evolving trends.

Questions: Why did you choose to post or not to post your picture on your Quora profile?
Answers:
At the risk of sounding like a douchebag, I’ve posted my picture because, in general, I like my face.

I want to show that some disabilities are invisible on the surface. I don’t look like I’m visually impaired.

I very much am.

You never know what's going on with people only by looking at them.

I think we should all celebrate what we like about ourselves. There's enough toxic shit to contend with out there. Enjoy what you actually like about yourself without worrying too much, I say.

I know full well that some people may think it's a ploy for upvotes and attention. Sure, it helps in some ways. It also works against me, too.

Because of my appearance, some people assume I might be vapid or shallow.

I'm not. You can read my answers and see for yourself.

And, anyway, I like the Quoraverse a lot and don't mind who knows it. Everybody’s got their reasons for showing or not showing their faces here and I respect them all. (:

Thanks for the A2A, Hugo Quinonez!

Questions: Why should (or shouldn't) you migrate your blog to Quora?
Answers:
As Joshua Heineman once wrote:

Creating a good blog is like writing a good book that no one reads past the first page. Creating a good blog is like hiding your treasure under piles of new treasure. Creating a bad blog is like burying your trash under piles of new trash.


One feature of Quora blogs that writers should value very highly, and which distinguishes Quora from other platforms: Quora surfaces content for reasons other than recency.

If you write something on Tumblr or Wordpress, your followers, RSS subscribers, and victims of your relentless cross-posting will see the post for minutes or hours, as it's slowly pushed down their dashboards, readers, inboxes, news feeds.

Your 10,000 word treatise, from the moment you post is, is expiring, decaying, fading from relevance, because most services and sites, due more to happenstance traditions of engineering and models, only care about recency.

As an author or creator, nothing is more frustrating than the web's inveterate indifference to quality when it's not associated with novelty. Only the new matters on Tumblr, Twitter, Facebook, and the like. The most important criterion of your work isn't its depth or utility, its accuracy or thoroughness, its beauty or value. All that matters is: is it at the top of the page?

Quora is different: if you write something strong about, say, jazz, and in a few years a user joins Quora and follows the relevant topics and people, they may see what you wrote. And they should, because whether it's new is just one trivial dimension of a post's value! (Meanwhile: things I worked very hard on, pieces which people seemed fond of, are hidden forever from new Tumblr users, unless they decide to waste their lives in my archive).

Indeed: it is depressing that this arbitrary and contingent chronological bias dominates the web, because it hides great content underneath whatever's new, and it obliges creators to repost, reuse, repeat, and worst of all: give up on the creation of enduringly valuable work. I think the consequences are pretty significant.

Other blogging platforms incentivize constant content. And that emphasis exists in opposition to any real evaluation —systematic or human— of a post's quality.

So: Quora restores the value of older, excellent work. It rescues your writing from immediate irrelevance and the great forgetting that defines much of the Internet. It puts work in taxonomic and substantive contexts, and attempts to promote the good, not the new. I hope they're very successful.

Questions: What are the best ideas for niche blogging in the field of pets?
Answers:
Niche blogging in the pet field can be rewarding and enjoyable, especially if you're passionate about animals. Here are some niche ideas within the pet blogging realm:

Holistic Pet Care: Focus on natural remedies, alternative therapies, and holistic pet health and wellness approaches.
Senior Pet Care: Cater to the needs of older pets, including health issues, nutrition, exercise, and mental stimulation.
Pet Travel: Offer tips, guides, and resources for traveling with pets, including pet-friendly destinations, accommodations, and transportation.
Exotic Pets: Specialize in care guides, husbandry tips, and general information for exotic pets like reptiles, amphibians, and small mammals.
Pet Photography: Share tips and tutorials on capturing beautiful photos of pets, including techniques, equipment reviews, and editing advice.
Pet Fashion: Showcase the latest trends in pet fashion, including clothing, accessories, and grooming styles.
Pet Adoption Stories: Share heartwarming stories of pets finding their forever homes, along with adoption tips, resources, and success stories.
Pet Loss and Grief Support: Provide resources, advice, and support for pet owners who have lost a beloved companion.
Pet Technology: Cover the latest gadgets, apps, and innovations designed to improve the lives of pets and pet owners.
Raw Feeding: Dive deep into the raw feeding diet for pets, including guides, recipes, and nutritional information.
DIY Pet Projects: Share creative DIY projects for pet owners, including homemade toys, beds, and grooming products.
Pet Behavior and Training: Offer training tips, behavior modification techniques, and advice for dealing with common behavioral issues in pets.
Urban Pet Living: Focus on the unique challenges and opportunities of raising pets in urban environments, including apartment living, city parks, and pet-friendly businesses.
Pet Fitness: Provide exercise routines, games, and activities to keep pets healthy and active, including tips for overweight or sedentary pets.
Pet-Friendly Gardening: Combine gardening tips with pet-friendly plant recommendations, landscaping ideas, and outdoor safety precautions for pets.

These niche ideas can help you stand out in the crowded pet blogging space and attract a dedicated audience interested in your specific area of expertise. Remember to choose a niche that aligns with your interests, knowledge, and the needs of your target audience.

Questions: How good of a writer do I have to be in order to write for Medium?
Answers:
You need to be at a point where:

You aren’t frequently messing up verb tenses or making other intermediate mistakes.
You understand the importance of Active Voice and idea/thought density.
You know how to structure an 800–1200 word article that is well organized, interesting, and not an information dump.

The latter point was my most difficult adjustment on the site when I started last year. Writing on Quora, we are used to having the topic handed to us and then writing 100–400 word blip answers.

I also had to lick my wounds initially. I’m so used to getting upvotes and praise on this platform that I thought my writing was better than it was.

The standards on Medium for writing are soooooo much higher than Quora (no offense). There aren’t “viral shitposts” on Medium like there are on Quora and Linkedin. It just doesn’t happen.

If your goal is to make money, you must be on top of your game. You need to push several high-quality articles per week that have original thoughts and ideas. If they don’t do well, you must evaluate why and pivot.

I’ve made great money on the site but I’ve been writing for a long time and I busted my butt writing and adapting on the platform this year.

Because there is legit money involved, Medium is very, very competitive. If English isn’t your first language, you’ll be facing an uphill battle as a writer. It won’t be impossible, some do it. But it will be very hard. I just don’t want people to waste their time.

Audiences on Medium are a lot more sophisticated (the fact that they pay money to read selects for quality readers). When they see minor things wrong in writing, they tune out. So bring your A-game. Best of luck!

Questions: Is the blogging business still a profitable one?
Answers: Yes, it can be done. This question is akin to asking the following.. Can someone make money by starting their own business ?  Here's the reality.. TONS  of people fail at starting a brick and mortar company yet it doesn't stop people from doing it. People have a host of questions and reservations about doing it and it requires far more capital to get going than blogging does. On the other hand, blogging when treated like a business carries with it the same realities and miseries too. There is potential to make a lot of money but there is an extremely high failure rate too.  Why ? Because for some reason, if you're doing it online it must be easier ? It's certainly more appealing but in large part, most people don't treat an online venture with the same seriousness, diligence and focus as they would in regards to something they are doing offline and that makes no sense at all, but it's the perspective that is out there.  It's up there with the comparison to someone that attends school online vs someone that doesn't. Supposedly doing it online means you're taking an easier route which couldn't be farther from the truth.  I would argue that blogging is one of the hardest things that anyone can venture into these days. Most with any remote interest in it don't have a clue as to how hard it is or about the time and work they are getting ready to commit themselves to if they want to experience success.  Consider this.. You can expect that if you start a blog today that you're going to have to do this for at least 2 years before you start to experience any kind of breakthrough with your blog in terms of traffic and momentum and we're not even talking about revenue generation yet. All this being said, assuming that you're taking a whitehat approach to this and avoiding blackhat methods.  Nevertheless.. YES it can be done but you've got a lot of work ahead of you.

Questions: What are the best sites to use for guest blogging if you want your material to be seen by an entrepreneur?
Answers:
I think the best way to think about this is to narrow down to more of a strategic level.

Who is the exact customer avatar? You say you want to talk to an Entrepreneur - but that’s super wide. What type of entrepreneur, in what phase of business, with what needs? Make sure to dial this in and get super clear on it
What is your goal? Besides just getting eyes on your name, what are you actually wanting to accomplish? Visits to your website, checking out a product, personal branding, PR, or getting credibility etc…

This is key to understanding the traffic types and where to put your focus.
Make a list of blogs/websites that match your customer criteria. Things like SEMrush and competition checking sites can give you more data on the visitors, type of customers, and interactions on sites over time. This should be thought about for which ones to do.
Reach out to Company marketing teams / Guest blogging contact forms. There’s no reason to guest post on smaller websites that don’t serve the customer avatar or serve your goal, so mark those off the list. Once you find the right ones, you’ll want to find the best ways to reach out. I’ve had great luck emailing/finding the marketing team through contact/support channels or using things like RocketReach to find the emails. Then, I approach with already thoughtful ideas that would benefit THEIR target user (not benefit me).
Establish the relationship with great content. Don’t go in with a me, me, me attitude. People want guest posters who deliver great content to their audience which will get them more eyes, likes, shares, and traffic. Make sure you are writing great content with real value for the users.

This is the strategy we used and it worked great! Got lots of guest posting places and great traffic from them.

That said, we all got a lot of links and outreach using things like HARO (help a reporter out).

Hope this helps!

Questions: What are some tips for writing blog content for clients?
Answers:
The most valuable skill for every copywriter - topic and sphere knowledge.

General articles sucks, every client of your client wants great, deep, useful content.

That’s why it’s valuable to dive deep to your client sphere.

How to do it fast?

Read at least 20–30 articles on relevant media
Read relevant subreddits
Ask questions you don’t understand: on reddit, ask your clients or friends from this sphere
Before starting to write an article (and even earlier - before creating a content plan) check if your topics and facts are not worn out and banal. Don’t write something that are already covered on 100500 blogs, if you can add a new facts or interesting view.

Questions: Why does Sean Kernan think writing for Medium is better than writing for your own blog?
Answers:
One reason: $$$

You can make great money on that site. For so long, there were no centralized places to get paid for writing. It was blogger platforms where you’d get paid pennies per million views. Most people burn out after a few posts.

Companies get so cheap about paying for writing and then wonder why their platforms stagnate. It has happened over and over again. I could list the graveyard of dead companies. There’s a ceiling any company will eventually reach if they don’t optimize for content, which mandates paying good wages to content creators.

Now, to you writers, you aren’t guaranteed to make good money if you write on Medium. I do really well but it’s super competitive. There are a lot of talented people vying for traffic, which, for Medium, is exactly what they want. Good compensation creates a competitive dynamic that churns out quality content for readers.

If you work at it and want to make money, you certainly can. Don’t get salty if you don’t. There will be winners and losers in any competitive system.
